awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project:  Infusing Computational Thinking and Visual Learning into an Introductory Computer Science Course to Promote Students' Success and Retention
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Morgan State University seeks to infuse critical thinking and other evidence-based strategies throughout the introductory computer science programming course taken annually by about 100 students. A strong plan for formative and summative evaluation is part of the project.

This project has the specific goals to: integrate and evaluate critical thinking skills with the existing curriculum alongside programming skills; teach general problem-solving techniques with a flowchart-based programming environment and without using specific programming concepts or languages at the beginning of the curriculum; put greater emphasis on core computer science principles with less of a focus on syntax by introducing Python as the introductory programming language; incorporate visual and interactive learning; and actively engage students in collaborative learning. The desired outcome is to retain more students in the Computer Science major and to prepare them for graduate studies and/or the workforce.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Award Title: Targeted Infusion Project:  Infusing Computational Thinking   and Visual Learning into an Introductory Computer Science Course to Promote Students Success and Retention

PI: Md Mahmudur Rahman

Federal Award ID: 1623335

Recipient Organization: Morgan State University (MSU)

This HBCU-UP targeted infusion project, without reinventing the wheel, infused several well-established pedagogies to create a dynamic classroom environment for teaching an introductory CS programming course in Python. An introductory programming course is among the most challenging in the computer science (CS) curriculum, particularly for the freshmen from minority or underrepresented population (around 85% at MSU) without any computing background. Within the overarching goal of creating an intellectual, active, and engaging academic environment and   improving students’ motivation towards programming and increasing retention, this project accomplished many of the objectives:

Infused Computational Thinking (CT) with the existing Curriculum: The project addresses different ways of problem solving, logical reasoning, algorithm design, and programming constructs with minimal or no emphasis on syntax. A CT framework is developed by identifying key concepts and a set of problem-solving strategies and practice activities are performed in a visual programming development environment (RAPTOR) based on flowcharts to allow a focus on CT principles right away.  Several teaching materials (e.g., lecture slides, exercises, quizzes, and small projects) are developed to infuse CT in addition to create an assessment (CT test) to gauge the ability of incoming students and measure the progress at the end of a semester. Improvement in performances were observed in between pre and post CT tests in several semesters which were during the project period.

Incorporated Interactive Learning in teaching Python: For a  dynamic classroom, an  interactive cloud-based  programming environment, Repl.it  is used  in instruction by letting  students  focus on coding, collaborate, and build  and minimizing the time spent acquiring, setting up, supporting, debugging, or adding a third-party package to an IDE.  To change the instructional approach to a studio model that combines the lecture and code simulation exercise in Repl.it during the same classroom period, an eBook (https://pybook.mdrahmanlab.com/) is created to interactively learn Python Programming.

Introduced Collaborative Learning as Team Projects: Project based collaborative learning is introduced   through teamwork on well-defined projects with well-crafted rubric where collaborations include use of basic task management tools, platforms, and multiplayer tool so that the students can critic, supplement, improve peer works and learn through the process.  The repl.it multiplayer feature helped in providing the collaborative ‘team-based’ learning environment intended for the students as this feature makes it possible for all members of the group to code on the same editor (like Google Docs) and execute their programs in the same interpreter.

This project is exploratory in nature and addressed the primary research question “does the proposed techniques increase student engagement, facilitate learning, and contribute to the progress of students in this course? The success is measured as 1) students’ global perception of Course Experience based on positive responses of survey result 2) improvement of CT skills as measured from pre and post CT tests and 3) preparedness of COSC 111 students for consequent courses. Robust statistical analysis proved the central research hypothesis of this project that programming proficiency of novice learners is dependent on the teaching approaches proposed in this project.  This project demonstrated gradual improvement in successive years by infusing the pedagogies incrementally based on mean quality points where the letter grade distributions were converted to quality points, then averaged by dividing by the number enrolled in a section.  The findings showed evidence to conclude that the proposed pedagogical approach increases student retention, engagement, and motivation in learning and improves student’s problem solving and coding skills.

This project helped several undergraduate minority students who worked as Teaching Assistants/Tutors throughout the project period, which eventually helped them financially and motivated them to being stay within the program, thereby increasing participation in CS by underrepresented minorities.

Outcomes of this project is widely disseminated for the benefit of the CS education community by  presenting (poster and oral) and publishing  in proceedings in several educational conferences, such as ACM SigCSE, IEEE Frontiers in Education, IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference (ISEC), AAC&U’s Transforming STEM Higher Education conference, and International Conference on Frontiers in Education: Computer Science and Computer Engineering (FECS) and International Computing Education Research conference (ICER).

Summary: This Targeted Infusion Project resulted in a faster acquisition of the needed skills and in producing more confidence in students in programming code development, positioning them well prepared for more advanced courses in the curriculum, and retaining them to continue in the CS program. The outcome of this project is far-reaching by retaining our minority students in CS major from under- represented and under-privileged background and producing an ample supply of work force to meet the growing needs of the STEM employers in US beyond just increasing student’s learning experience and motivation toward programming.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Md M Rahman

PI: Md Mahmudur Rahman
Federal Award ID: 1623335
Recipient Organization: Morgan State University (MSU)

This HBCU-UP targeted infusion project, without reinventing the wheel, infused several well-established pedagogies to create a dynamic classroom environment for teaching an introductory CS programming course in Python. An introductory programming course is among the most challenging in the computer science (CS) curriculum, particularly for the freshmen from minority or underrepresented population (around 85% at MSU) without any computing background. Within the overarching goal of creating an intellectual, active, and engaging academic environment and   improving students’ motivation towards programming and increasing retention, this project accomplished many of the objectives:
Infused Computational Thinking (CT) with the existing Curriculum: The project addresses different ways of problem solving, logical reasoning, algorithm design, and programming constructs with minimal or no emphasis on syntax. A CT framework is developed by identifying key concepts and a set of problem-solving strategies and practice activities are performed in a visual programming development environment (RAPTOR) based on flowcharts to allow a focus on CT principles right away. To change the instructional approach to a studio model that combines the lecture and code simulation exercise in Repl.it during the same classroom period, an eBook (https://pybook.mdrahmanlab.com/) is created to interactively learn Python Programming.

The repl.it multiplayer feature helped in providing the collaborative ‘team-based’ learning environment intended for the students as this feature makes it possible for all members of the group to code on the same editor (like Google Docs) and execute their programs in the same interpreter.
This project is exploratory in nature and addressed the primary research question "does the proposed techniques increase student engagement, facilitate learning, and contribute to the progress of students in this course? The findings showed evidence to conclude that the proposed pedagogical approach increases student retention, engagement, and motivation in learning and improves student’s problem solving and coding skills.
This project helped several undergraduate minority students who worked as Teaching Assistants/Tutors throughout the project period, which eventually helped them financially and motivated them to being stay within the program, thereby increasing participation in CS by underrepresented minorities.
Outcomes of this project is widely disseminated for the benefit of the CS education community by  presenting (poster and oral) and publishing  in proceedings in several educational conferences, such as ACM SigCSE, IEEE Frontiers in Education, IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference (ISEC), AAC&U’s Transforming STEM Higher Education conference, and International Conference on Frontiers in Education: Computer Science and Computer Engineering (FECS) and International Computing Education Research conference (ICER).
